instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> from hell
threads.message:
Good evening people, 
I have received not 1 but 2 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with the same issue but not with the same problem.

One of them power cycles, and the other one does nothing.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>  goes up and down on the one that cycles, and on the other one is 0v.
no shorts on any rail.
Any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> from hell
threads.message: Probably dead CPU like every other 12" MacBook. If customer needs data, reflow/reball CPU is a good option. If no data needed, then trash.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> from hell
threads.message:
Probably hopeless project.
Check for short on big coils, try to start in SMC bypass mode.
Compare diode mode readings on the power rails between both boards.
